Title: Demographic Attributes of Knowledge, Attitude, Practices, and One Health Perspective Regarding Diarrhea in Pakistan.
Study Population: University students living in urban and rural populations of Rawalpindi and Islamabad, Pakistan
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Dates are approximate, Sampling from July to December 2020
Location Description: universities of the twin cities: the capital Islamabad and Rawalpindi. The terrain consists of plains and mountains in the metropolitan area of Islamabad and Rawalpindi, whose total area exceeds 1,175 m.
Care Seeking Questions:
Will you visit the doctor if you are having diarrhea (attitude; would seek care)
Do you visit the doctor immediately after encountering diarrhea (behavior; did they seek care)
Additional Information: "may be" answers were assigned a "no" value

Title: Prevalence of diarrheal illness and healthcare-seeking behavior by age-group and sex among the population of Gaza strip: a community-based cross-sectional study
Study Population: Heads of households in the Gaza Strip
Case Definition: passage of three or more abnormally loose, watery, or liquid stools over a 24-h period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: Urban area is defined as a region with high population density and infrastructure of built environment
Care Seeking Questions: Did you seek professional healthcare for diarrhea
Additional Information: Questions are about the household; not specific to one patient

Title: Diarrhea Prevention Practice and Associated Factors among Caregivers of Under-Five Children in Enemay District, Northwest Ethiopia

Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Comments: Rural description determined by Central Statistical Agency (CSA) data from 2007 table 2.1

Title: Incidence of Acute Diarrhea-Associated Death among Children < 5 Years of Age in Bangladesh, 2010–12
Study Population: children <5 years that died due to diarrhea
Case Definition: acute diarrhea-associated death as deaths among children who experienced sudden onset of loose, watery stools for three or more times in 24 hours for at least 2 days within 14 days of death and who died in the same illness episode
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Social network approach
Dates are approximate - deaths that occured from May 2010-April 2012
Location Description: Across the total country; based off the catchment areas of 20 study unions
Care Seeking Questions: What is the highest level of treatent sought for diarrhea

Title: Incidence of Acute Diarrhea-Associated Death among Children < 5 Years of Age in Bangladesh, 2010–12

Title: Predictors of Health-Care Utilization Among Children 6-59 Months of Age in Zambézia Province, Mozambique.
Study Population: Female heads of households in the Zambézia Province
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: All provinces
Care Seeking Questions: Among those with diarrhea, sought treatment at health facility
Additional Information: converted from percentages
Comments: Converted 59 months to 5 years for upper age bound; 0.5 years is 6 months

Title: Household Management of Childhood Diarrhoea: A Population-based Study in Nicaragua
Study Population: Parents or caretakers of children below five years of age who developed diarrhoea from León, Nicaragua
Case Definition: An increase in stool frequency to at least three stools per 24- hour period or a substantial change in stool consistency to loose, watery, or bloody, following at least three diarrhoea-free days
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: León; second largest city in Nicaragua
Care Seeking Questions: Where from did child recieve care for diaarhoea

Title: Community-based cluster surveys on treatment preferences for diarrhoea, severe diarrhoea, and dysentery in children aged less than five years in two districts of Ghana
Study Population: Caretakers of children under 5 years of age in Ghana
Case Definition: severe diarrhea - lasting less than 14 days and meeting one of the following three definitions: (1) more than three loose or watery stools in a 24-period with no blood and at least two of the following: lethargy/unconsciousness, sunken eyes, inability to drink or drinking poorly; or (2) local name for severe diarrhoea; or (3) diarrhoea for which the child received intravenous rehydration
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: September-October 2002
Care Seeking Questions: Place of care for severe diarrhea
Diarrhea severity: severe diarrhea - lasting less than 14 days and meeting one of the following three definitions: (1) more than three loose or watery stools in a 24-period with no blood and at least two of the following: lethargy/unconsciousness, sunken eyes, inability to drink or drinking poorly; or (2) local name for severe diarrhoea; or (3) diarrhoea for which the child received intravenous rehydration
Comments: Overlapping because severe diarrhea and dysentary are categories of/included within all reported diarrhea
Overlaps decision: severe and dysentary are included within all diarrhea

Title: Healthcare-use for Major Infectious Disease Syndromes in an Informal Settlement in Nairobi, Kenya
Study Population: Children aged less than five years residing in Gatwikira and Soweto villages
Case Definition: Three or more loose stools over at least a 24-hour period during the two weeks before interview
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: Article context is about urbanization in kenya;  Gatwikira and Soweto part of Kiberia slum
Care Seeking Questions:
Any care sought outside the household?
Visited any healthcare facility?
Additional Information: some had >1 healthcare encounter; Extracted the “hospital” data rather than the “any healthcare facility data” because it is more specific. Assuming that cholera treatment centers or clinics are included in the “hospital” definition and not lost by not using the “any healthcare facility” category

Title: Predictors of diarrhea episodes and treatment-seeking behavior in under-five children: a longitudinal study from rural communities in Zambia
Study Population: children aged between 12 and 59 months
Case Definition: passing of loose stool at least three (3) times per day
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: Surveyed the catchment areas of Chivuna and Magoye Rural Health Centers (RHC). Chivuna and Magoye areas are generally flat lands with numerous streams, although Chivuna is hilly in some areas. During the rainy season, some of the households are difficult to access by vehicle because of the bad roads and lack of bridges across some of the stream. Magoye RHC is situated along the main tarred road linking Southern Province to Lusaka (the capital city of Zambia), whilst Chivuna RHC lies 37 km from the same main road and southeast of Magoye RHC. As a result, this exposes the two catchment populations to slightly different economic environments, which could impact their health-seeking behaviors
Care Seeking Questions: What was the source of treatment for diarrhea?

Title: Community mortality from cholera: urban and rural districts in Zimbabwe

Additional Information: about household member with cholera

Title: Health care seeking for childhood diarrhea in developing countries: evidence from seven sites in Africa and Asia
Study Population: Children aged 0-59 months in the DSS database
Case Definition: three or more abnormally loose stools in a 24-hour period according to the caretaker
Study Context: populations were a part of the GEMS study
Outbreak Description: no outbreak description
Notes: Only HUAS results used in this extraction, thus study design variables reflect only HUAS methods; HUAS surveys conducted in 2007, exact dates assumed
Location Description: located in rural settings
Care Seeking Questions: What was the first point of care sought?
Additional Information: Not all care-seeking options were extracted (Table 3) [excluded unlicensed practitioner and bought remedy from market]
Comments: care-seeking data weighted, according to age and sex distribution in the demographic surveillance system population at each site. Percentages provided in Table 3 sum to greater than 100%

Title: Health Care-Seeking Behavior During Childhood Diarrheal Illness: Results of Health Care Utilization and Attitudes Surveys of Caretakers in Western Kenya, 2007–2010
Study Population: caretakers of children under 5 years old
Case Definition:
LSD: more than or equal to three loose stools within the previous 24 hours
MSD: same as LSD but with one or more of the following characteristics: sunken eyes, loss of skin turgot, dysentery (blood in stool), receipt of intravenous rehydration, or required hospitalization
Outbreak Description: no outbreak description
Location Description: This region reports the highest adult human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) prevalence rates (approximately 15%) in Kenya.16,17 Malaria transmission is high and holoendemic.1
Additional Information: round 1 of HUAS-lite
Diarrhea symptoms: diarrhea with one or more of the following: sunken eyes, loss of skin turgor, dysentery, receipt of IV rehydration, or required hospitalization

MSD: same as LSD but with one or more of the following characteristics: sunken eyes, loss of skin turgot, dysentery (blood in stool), receipt of intravenous rehydration, or required hospitalization
Outbreak Description: no outbreak description
Location Description: This region reports the highest adult human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) prevalence rates (approximately 15%) in Kenya.16,17 Malaria transmission is high and holoendemic.24
Additional Information: overall (round 1-5)
Diarrhea symptoms: diarrhea with absence of any characteristic of MSD

Title: Danger signs of neonatal illnesses: perceptions of caregivers and health workers in northern India
Study Population: Primary caregivers of o a newborn within the last 6 months who were permanent residents of the village
Study Context: At time of the study, IMNCI had not been introduced in the area
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from May through November 2005, exact dates assumed
Location Description: 80% of Sarojaninagar is rural; consists of 190 villages
Care Seeking Questions: After recognition of signs of diarrhea, would you seek medical care?

Title: Knowledge, Attitudes and Practices on Cholera and Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene among Internally Displaced Persons in Cabo Delgado Province, Mozambique.
Study Population: Internally displaced persons living within specified relocation sites in Cabo Delgado
Case Definition: Cholera
Study Context: Since 2017, Mozambique has been facing a severe humanitarian crisis due to ongoing conflicts and natural disasters.
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
GADM Admin 2, when available: Ancuabe, Chiure, Mecufi, Metuge, Montepuez, Pemba
Urban or Rural: IDP Camp (Internally Displaced Person) or Refugee Camp
Care Seeking Questions: If you had cholera, would you go to a traditional healer?
Additional Information: Used a Likert-scale; Answers of "neither" agree/disgaree", "disagree" and "strongly disagree" counted as no

Title: Knowledge, Attitudes and Practices on Cholera and Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene among Internally Displaced Persons in Cabo Delgado Province, Mozambique.

Urban or Rural: IDP Camp (Internally Displaced Person) or Refugee Camp
Care Seeking Questions: If you had cholera, would you go to the cholera treatment center/hospital?
Additional Information: Used a Likert-scale; Answers of "neither" agree/disgaree", "disagree" and "strongly disagree" counted as no

Care Seeking Questions: Did you seek medical care subsequent to experience of diarrhea?

Title: Prevalence of malnutrition, diarrhea, and acute respiratory infections among under-five children of Sugali tribe of Chittoor district, Andhra Pradesh, India
Study Population: Caretakers of children under five who are part of the Sugali tribe
Case Definition: Three or more loose stools in past 1 month. For children below 6 months, a recent change in the consistency of stool and water content more than fecal matter was defined as diarrhea
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Additional Information: recall period 1 month, one month is assumed to be 30 days.

Title: Prevalence of malnutrition, diarrhea, and acute respiratory infections among under-five children of Sugali tribe of Chittoor district, Andhra Pradesh, India
Study Population: Caretakers of children under five who are part of the Sugali tribe
Case Definition: Three or more loose stools in past 1 month. For children below 6 months, a recent change in the consistency of stool and water content more than fecal matter was defined as diarrhea
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Additional Information: recall period 1 month, one month is assumed to be 30 days.

Title: A population-based study on healthcare-seeking behaviour of persons with symptoms of respiratory and gastrointestinal-related infections in Hong Kong
Study Population: Children and adults in Hong Kong
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from four rounds carried out between February 2014 through May 2015, exact dates assumed; Caregivers were surveyed for information on children under 16.
Additional Information: Healthcare services included private general practitioners (GP), public general outpatient clinics (GOPC), Chinese medicine practitioner clinics (CMP), and Accident and Emergency Department (A&E)

Title: Geographic Distribution and Mortality Risk Factors during the Cholera Outbreak in a Rural Region of Haiti, 2010-2011
Study Population: Heads of households within rural villages in Nord, Haiti
Case Definition:
Diarrhea: at least three watery stools within a 24-hour period
Severe diarrhea: self-reported lethargy or altered consciousness during the diarrheal illness
Outbreak Description: Cholera epidemic began in 2010; 600,000 cases of cholera and 7,000 deaths reported within first two years
Location Description: Villages in the districts of Plaisance and Port Margot are mainly accessible by roads, while villages in the more mountainous districts of Pilate and Borgne are more difficult to reach due to their mountainous terrain
Facility or location sought as written i: Médecins Sans Frontières/Cholera treatment center/cholera treatment units
Additional Information: Recall period from beginning of epidemic through beginning of study; Médecins Sans Frontières = doctors without borders
Comments: Data extrated manually from study's excel datasheet by MHM using pivot tables in excel. Worksheet showing extraction process can be found in Extraction file in Care Seeking Review channel on Teams

Diarrhea: at least three watery stools within a 24-hour period
Severe diarrhea: self-reported lethargy or altered consciousness during the diarrheal illness
Outbreak Description: Cholera epidemic began in 2010; 600,000 cases of cholera and 7,000 deaths reported within first two years
Location Description: Villages in the districts of Plaisance and Port Margot are mainly accessible by roads, while villages in the more mountainous districts of Pilate and Borgne are more difficult to reach due to their mountainous terrain
Additional Information: Recall period from beginning of epidemic through beginning of study

Diarrhea: at least three watery stools within a 24-hour period
Severe diarrhea: self-reported lethargy or altered consciousness during the diarrheal illness
Outbreak Description: Cholera epidemic began in 2010; 600,000 cases of cholera and 7,000 deaths reported within first two years
Location Description: Villages in the districts of Plaisance and Port Margot are mainly accessible by roads, while villages in the more mountainous districts of Pilate and Borgne are more difficult to reach due to their mountainous terrain
Facility or location sought as written i: Non- Médecins Sans Frontières/Cholera treatment center/cholera treatment units
Additional Information: Recall period from beginning of epidemic through beginning of study; Médecins Sans Frontières = doctors without borders
Comments: Data extrated manually from study's excel datasheet by MHM using pivot tables in excel. Worksheet showing extraction process can be found in Extraction file in Care Seeking Review channel on Teams

Case Definition:
Diarrhea: at least three watery stools within a 24-hour period
Severe diarrhea: self-reported lethargy or altered consciousness during the diarrheal illness
Outbreak Description: Cholera epidemic began in 2010; 600,000 cases of cholera and 7,000 deaths reported within first two years
Location Description: Villages in the districts of Plaisance and Port Margot are mainly accessible by roads, while villages in the more mountainous districts of Pilate and Borgne are more difficult to reach due to their mountainous terrain
Additional Information:
Recall period from beginning of epidemic through beginning of study
Heads of household answered for all household members on past illness, thus reports could be about themselves or another person in the house
Comments: Data extrated manually from study's excel datasheet by MHM using pivot tables in excel. Worksheet showing extraction process can be found in Extraction file in Care Seeking Review channel on Teams

Case Definition:
Diarrhea: at least three watery stools within a 24-hour period
Severe diarrhea: self-reported lethargy or altered consciousness during the diarrheal illness
Outbreak Description: Cholera epidemic began in 2010; 600,000 cases of cholera and 7,000 deaths reported within first two years
Location Description: Villages in the districts of Plaisance and Port Margot are mainly accessible by roads, while villages in the more mountainous districts of Pilate and Borgne are more difficult to reach due to their mountainous terrain
Additional Information:
Recall period from beginning of epidemic through beginning of study
Heads of household answered for all household members on past illness, thus reports could be about themselves or another person in the house
Comments: Data extrated manually from study's excel datasheet by MHM using pivot tables in excel. Worksheet showing extraction process can be found in Extraction file in Care Seeking Review channel on Teams

Title: Acute gastrointestinal illness in adults in Germany: a population-based telephone survey
Study Population: Resident German-speaking adult population living in private households with a fixed telephone line (landline).
Case Definition: Acute gastroenteritis illness: self reported diarrhea or vomitting. Diarrhea was defined as 3 or more loose stools in a 24 hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from July 2008 to June 2009, exact dates assumed; telephone survey
Location Description: Sample from across country, no specific area
Additional Information: Either doctor in private practice or medical service in hospital without hospitalization.

Title: Acute gastrointestinal illness in adults in Germany: a population-based telephone survey
Study Population: Resident German-speaking adult population living in private households with a fixed telephone line (landline).
Case Definition: Acute gastroenteritis illness: self reported diarrhea or vomitting. Diarrhea was defined as 3 or more loose stools in a 24 hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from July 2008 to June 2009, exact dates assumed; telephone survey
Location Description: Sample from across country, no specific area
Additional Information: medical service in hospital that led to hospitalization

Title: Estimating the Burden of Acute Gastroenteritis and Foodborne Illness Caused by Campylobacter, Salmonella, and Vibrio parahaemolyticus by Using Population-Based Telephone Survey Data, Miyagi Prefecture, Japan, 2005 to 2006
Study Population: Children and adults in Miyagi, Japan
Case Definition: three or more loose stools or any vomiting within 24 h
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: telephone survey
Location Description: Miyagi made up of urban, rural and peri-urban areas
Additional Information: Those 12 or older answered for themselves and guardians answered for those under 12

Title: Estimating the Burden of Acute Gastroenteritis and Foodborne Illness Caused by Campylobacter, Salmonella, and Vibrio parahaemolyticus by Using Population-Based Telephone Survey Data, Miyagi Prefecture, Japan, 2005 to 2006
Study Population: Children and adults in Miyagi, Japan
Case Definition: three or more loose stools or any vomiting within 24 h
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: telephone survey
Location Description: Miyagi made up of urban, rural and peri-urban areas
Additional Information: Those 12 or older answered for themselves and guardians answered for those under 12

Title: Health care seeking practices of caregivers of children under 5 with diarrhea in two informal settlements in Nairobi, Kenya
Study Population: Caregivers of children under five who reside in Korogocho or Viwandani
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Nested into the Nairobi Urban Health Demographic Surveillance System (DSS) that has been running since 2002, followed up all children born in the DSS area
Location Description: Informal settlements; slum

Title: Recurrent epidemic cholera with high mortality in Cameroon: persistent challenges 40 years into the seventh pandemic
Study Population: Relatives, survivors, and relatives of survivors of Cholera residing in a village that reported both a cholera death and cholera case since September 2009 in Extreme North Cameroon
Case Definition: Death from acute, watery diarrhoea (10–100 unobstructed, involuntary stools per day), dehydration, and anuria
Outbreak Description: Cases had been reported from 10 of the 28 districts of the Far North region, nine of the 13 districts in the North region, and in neighboring areas of Nigeria. A total of 717 cholera cases and 85 deaths
Notes: Cases were suspected cholera deaths identified using Ministry of Health surveillance list compiled from district medical officer reports. Controls were any person, 5 or older, that survived a cholera-like illness and lived in a study village
GADM Admin 2, when available: Mayo Sava, Mayo Sava, Mayo Tsanaga, Mayo Tsanaga, Mayo Tsanaga, Mayo Tsanaga
GADM Admin 3, when available: Mora, Kolofata, Soul√©d√© Roua, Mogod√©, Hina, Bourha
Location Description: 14 villages from 6 districts surveyed
Additional Information: relative of person who died

Title: Cholera Mortality during Urban Epidemic, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, August 16, 2015-January 16, 2016
Study Population: Caretakers of cholera decedents who died on or after August 15, 2015 in Dar es Salaam
Case Definition: Cholera death was death of a person ≥2 years of age with acute watery diarrhea with or without vomiting OR a death of a person ≥2 years of age whose stool was positive for Vibrio cholerae O1
Outbreak Description: Tanzania reported an outbreak of cholera on August 15, 2015; Early in the Tanzania outbreak, most cases and deaths were reported in Dar es Salaam, where 3,371 cases and 36 deaths had been recorded by October 31, 2015
Notes: Cases identified using reports from cholera treatment centers or from burial permit assessments; caretakers interviewed on care-seeking behavior of decedents
Additional Information: caretakers included family members, landlords, neighbors, employees and friends

Title: Health seeking behaviour among suspected cases of cholera in Cameroonian health districts in Lake Chad basin
Study Population: Patients who presented with acute watery diarrhoea and dehydration attending health facilities
Case Definition: suspected cholera: acute watery diarrhea and dehydration
Study Context: Cameroon has registered numerous cholera outbreaks between 1971 and 2015; area was selected for the study as it is a hotspot for cholera outbreaks in Cameroon.
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from August 2013-October 2015, exact dates assumed
Location Description: districts in the Lake Chad basin; Kousseri district capital; selected facilities treat suspect cases from Cameroon as well as from neighbouring countries including Chad, Niger or Nigeria
Care Seeking Questions: Where did the patient first seek care?
Additional Information: Patients 10 and older self reported, for those under 10 answers provided by parent, sibling, legal guardian or other about the child

Title: Epidemiological and microbiological investigation of a large outbreak of monophasic Salmonella Typhimurium 4,5,12:i:- in schools associated with imported beef in Poitiers, France, October 2010
Study Population: Students or personnel attending schools in Poitiers that were served contaminated frozen beef burgers
Case Definition: A person having eaten the school meal on the day the incriminated beef was served and reporting either: (i) diarrhoea within five days after school meal, or (ii) fever with at least one digestive symptom (nausea, vomiting or abdominal pain) within five days after school meal, or (iii) diarrhoea of unknown date of onset but within 15 days after the incriminated school meal, or (iv) fever with at least one digestive symptom and with unknown date of symptoms within 15 days after the school meal.
Study Context: During a Salmonella Typhimurium 4,5,12:i outbreak resulting from contaminated frozen burgers
Outbreak Description: This multi-school outbreak is one of the biggest food-borne outbreaks due to monophasic Salmonella Typhimurium 4,5,12:i:- described in France
Notes: Sampling from October 2010, exact dates assumed
Location Description: 4 schools identified, including 2 junior high school and 2 senior high school
Additional Information: Majority of cases (534) occurred among those under 20 years of age

Title: Care-seeking and quality of care for outpatient sick children in rural Hebei, China: a cross-sectional study
Study Population: Caregivers of children under two in Zhao County
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from July 2011, exact dates assumed; Used the Maternal, Newborn and Child Health survey developed by WHO
Care Seeking Questions: Was care sought outside the home?

Title: Knowledge and practices of mothers and caregivers on diarrhoeal management among under 5-year-old children in a medium-size town of Senegal
Study Population: Mothers or caregivers of child under 5
Case Definition: three or more loose or watery bowel movements within 24 h
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from September through October, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Zones included: (i) urban central area (UCA); (ii) peri-central area (PCA); (iii) north peripheral area (NPA); and (iv) south peripheral area (SPA)
Care Seeking Questions: Where did you go for advice or treatment?
Additional Information: Including hospitals, health centres and health posts

Case Definition: three or more loose or watery bowel movements within 24 h
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from September through October, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Urban central area
Care Seeking Questions: Where did you go for advice or treatment?
Additional Information: Including clinics, pharmacies and dispensaries.

Title: Mothers’ knowledge, attitude and practice towards the prevention and home-based management of diarrheal disease among under-five children in Diredawa, Eastern Ethiopia, 2016: a cross-sectional study
Study Population: Mothers who had a child less than 5 years of age with diarrhea in the last 2 weeks attending select hospitals in Dire Diwa
Case Definition: Self-reported
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Most of the mothers (92.5%), defined diarrhea as the passing of loose stool 3 or more times per day
Location Description: 68.23% of the population were urban inhabitants, while 31.77% were rural inhabitants.
Care Seeking Questions: Where did you first go for advice or treatment

Title: Household costs of seeking outpatient care in Egyptian children with diarrhea: a cross-sectional study
Study Population: Caregivers accompanying children under 12 years presenting with acute diarrhea at the outpatient clinics of Pediatric Specialized Hospital of Cairo University.
Case Definition: three or more loose  bowel movements during a 24-h period
Study Context: study period was during peak of diarrheal season
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from May through November 2011; exact dates assumed
Location Description: Study done at the outpatient clinics of Pediatric Specialized Hospital of Cairo University. This facility is the largest pediatric teaching referral hospital in Egypt with 600 beds.
Care Seeking Questions: What was the first sought provider?

Title: Responses to hypothetical health scenarios overestimate healthcare utilization for common infectious syndromes: a cross-sectional survey, South Africa, 2013
Study Population: Self-identified primary caregiver of child with diarrhea
Case Definition: ≥3 loose or watery stools within a 24 h period in a child < 5 years of age
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Sampling from larger survey (did seek care) July through October 2012; exact dates assumed
Respondents who reported an actual episode of the infectious syndrome within the household were excluded from the analysis of intended healthcare utilization
GADM Admin 2, when available: City of Johannesurg, Dr Kenneth Kaunda
Location Description: Soweto, an urban township outside Johannesburg, and the peri-urban townships surrounding Klerksdorp, including Jouberton, Alabama, Sakhroi, Kanana, Khuma, Tigane, Dominionville, and Vaal Reef
Care Seeking Questions: Where did you first seek care?
Overlaps decision: overlaps with Study ID #73 ; Study ID #73 listed as primary dataset

Title: Under-reporting of infectious gastrointestinal illness in British Columbia, Canada: who is counted in provincial communicable disease statistics?
Study Population: Residents from three public health regions in the province of BC, Canada
Case Definition: Acute IGI were defined as individuals who reported any vomiting or diarrhoea (any loose stool or stool with abnormal liquidity) of presumed infectious origin
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from June 2002 through June 2003, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Includes urban and rural locations; combined population of these regions represented around 19% of the total provincial population

Title: Estimating the Burden of Acute Gastrointestinal Illness: A Pilot Study of the Prevalence and Underreporting in Saint Lucia, Eastern Caribbean
Study Population: Individuals in Saint Lucia
Case Definition: AGE defined as anyone who experienced diarrhoea, resulting in 3 or more loose stools in a 24-hour period and who did not declare to have a chronic condition causing diarrhoea
Study Context: Part of Caribbean Burden of Illness (BOI) Study led by CAREC in collaboration with Pan American Health Organization (PAHO)
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from April–16 May 2008 (Phase 1: high-AGE season) and 6-13 December 2009 (Phase 2: low-AGE season
Location Description: includes all of St. Lucia, urban and rural

Title: Measuring the Impact of Rotavirus Acute Gastroenteritis Episodes (MIRAGE): A prospective community-based study
Study Population: Patients presenting with gastroenteritis enrolled from 59 medical practices in select Canadian provinces
Case Definition: At least three watery or looserthan-normal stools, or forceful vomiting within the previous 24 h period; RV status determined by enzyme-linked immunoassay testing
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Participants excluded if current gastroenteritis symptom onset was more than seven days before enrollment, if they had received treatment with antibiotics or immunoglobulins within 30 days before study entry, if the patient or the patient’s mother was positive for HIV, hepatitis B or C, or had participated in an RV immunization program
GADM Admin 1, when available: British Columbia, Manitoba, Nova Scotia, Ontario, Qu√©bec, Saskatchewan
Location Description: Enrolling sites by province: Ontario (n=34), Quebec (n=12), British Columbia (n=7), Manitoba (n=3), Saskatchewan (n=2) and Nova Scotia (n=1)

Title: Care-seeking behaviour and diagnostic processes for symptomatic giardiasis in children attending an academic paediatric hospital
Study Population: Caregivers of children who were treated at the Academic Paediatric Hospital ‘Centro Habana’ (APHCH) for childhood giardiasis
Case Definition: Initial giardiasis-related clinical manifestations including continuous diarrhoea (defined as a change in the normal pattern of bowel movements with at least three loose stools daily, lasting for at least 4 days); intermittent diarrhoea (defined as complete resolution of diarrhoea for 24 or more hours followed by return of symptoms), abdominal pain, vomiting, decreased appetite, and weight loss
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: APHCH provides services to those from all over Cuba, but mainly for children from the Centro Habana, Plaza, Cerro, and Habana vieja municipalities

Additional Information: In rural China, village clinics, township hospitals and county hospitals form a three-tier health service system

Title: Rapid Assessment of Cholera-related Deaths, Artibonite Department, Haiti, 2010
Study Population: caregivers of cholera decedents in Artibonite
Case Definition: cholera decedents as persons who died of suspected cholera (acute watery diarrhea in persons >5 years of age)
Outbreak Description: cholera outbreak confirmed 10/21/2010; As of 11/13/2010: 16,111 persons hospitalized with suspected cholera and 992 cholera-related deaths, for a CFR of 6.2%.
Notes:
decedents found using reports of cholera related deaths from admission records from 2 hospitals in Artibonite that had cholera treatment centers and verbal reports from community health workers
limited case finding to communities within 2 hours’ travel from the hospitals
Care Seeking Questions: When and where did the death occur?
Additional Information:
Household members of the decedent were surveyed, could be their child or other household member;
Those who sought care include those who died in a health facility and those who died at home after discharge

Title: Knowledge, Attitude, and Practice in a Sample of the Lebanese Population Regarding Cholera
Study Population: All people residing in Lebanon aged 18 years or older
Study Context: During a cholera outbreak "which can be linked to the consequences of a humanitarian crisis that resulted in the disruption of water and sanitation systems, besides the displacement of populations to overcrowded camps with inadequate access to clean water and sanitation with subsequent increased risk of cholera transmission"
Outbreak Description: In October 2022, an outbreak of cholera was reported in Lebanon, which is the first to be reported in the Middle Eastern country for 30 years
Notes:
Data were collected through an electronic self-administered questionnaire using snowball sampling. The questionnaire link was shared through social media outlets including WhatsApp, Facebook, and LinkedIn and was available for the complete duration of the study
Sampling from October 2022 through November 2022, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Across Lebanon
Care Seeking Questions: Would you go here if you suspect cholera infection?
Additional Information: Answers of "I do not know" assumed to be no

Title: Compliance with referral of sick children: a survey in five districts of Afghanistan
Study Population: Caregivers of sick children in the past two weeks
Study Context: Baseline survey in a study to understand issues with the functioning of the referral system for children
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Sampling from 2009, exact dates assumed
Lot quality assurance sampling method applied-130 households selected in each district and then that household, or the nearest household, with a sick child in the past 2 weeks surveyed

Title: Compliance with referral of sick children: a survey in five districts of Afghanistan
Study Population: Caregivers of sick children in the past two weeks
Study Context: Baseline survey in a study to understand issues with the functioning of the referral system for children
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Sampling from 2009, exact dates assumed
Lot quality assurance sampling method applied-130 households selected in each district and then that household, or the nearest household, with a sick child in the past 2 weeks surveyed
GADM Admin 2, when available: Ghoryan, Farkhar, Qarqin, Gul dara, Bamyan City
Comments: Farza and Shahfoladi determined to be in their respective districts using google maps and Afghanistan's GADM shapefile in ArcGIS

Title: Healthcare utilization for common infectious disease syndromes in Soweto and Klerksdorp, South Africa
Study Population: Primary caregiver of child with diarrhea
Case Definition: ≥3 loose or watery stools within a 24 h period in a child < 5 years of age
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from July through October 2012; exact dates assumed
Location Description: Peri-urban townships surrounding Klerksdorp, including Jouberton, Alabama, Sakhroi, Kanana, Khuma, Tigane, Dominionville, and Vaal Reef
Care Seeking Questions: All healthcare facilities and providers consulted by persons reporting diarrhea
Overlaps decision: Overlaps with Study ID 62, this study listed as primary dataset due to geographic stratification

Title: Acute Gastroenteritis in Ireland, North and South
Study Population: Residents in South Ireland (Republic of Ireland)
Case Definition: diarrhoea: three or more times in a 24-hour period or bloody diarrhoea or vomiting together with at least one other symptom
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from December 2000-November 2001, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Population level, includes all areas urban and rural
Care Seeking Questions: respondents were asked if they had consulted a GP, attended a hospital casualty department
Additional Information: For those under 12 years, a parent or guardian was asked to conduct the interview on the child’s behalf. For those aged 12—16 years, a parent or guardian was given the option of answering on the child’s behalf or consenting for the child to be interviewed. 17 and over self-reported

Title: Acute Gastroenteritis in Ireland, North and South
Study Population: Residents in South Ireland (Republic of Ireland)
Case Definition: diarrhoea: three or more times in a 24-hour period or bloody diarrhoea or vomiting together with at least one other symptom
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from December 2000-November 2001, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Population level, includes all areas urban and rural
Care Seeking Questions: respondents were asked if they had consulted a GP, attended a hospital casualty department
Additional Information: For those under 12 years, a parent or guardian was asked to conduct the interview on the child’s behalf. For those aged 12—16 years, a parent or guardian was given the option of answering on the child’s behalf or consenting for the child to be interviewed. 17 and over self-reported

Title: Factors influencing the low utilization of curative child health services in Shebedino District, Sidama Zone, Ethiopia.
Study Population: Mothers with children under 1
Study Context: After iCCM training at health posts and project evaluation reported under-utilization
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Used Lot Quality Assurance Sampling to randomly select 19 households from each of the districts supervision areas; Sampling from May 2011, exact dates assumed

Title: Promotion of Zinc Tablets with ORS through Child Health Weeks Improves Caregiver Knowledge, Attitudes, and Practice on Treatment of Diarrhoea in Nigeria
Study Population: Caregivers who had under-five children with diarrhoeal episode in the last 3 months prior to the Maternal, Newborn and Child Health Weeks (MNCHW) education campaign
Study Context: Meant to evaulate the pre-MNCHW education campaign and counselling provided to caregivers
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from November 2010, exact dates assumed
Care Seeking Questions: Was care sought outside the home?
Facility or location sought as written i: outside the home (health facility or chemist)
Additional Information: 3 months assumed to be 90 days

Case Definition: Diarrhea: passage of loose stool at least three times a day or more frequent than normal for under-five children
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from July 2010, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Home to indigenous people
Care Seeking Questions: What did you do when your child got diarrhoea?

Title: Comparing sociocultural features of cholera in three endemic African settings
Study Population: Adults in Chumbuni and Muambe
Outbreak Description: In the current pandemic, cholera was reported for the first time in 1978 [47]. More than 13 outbreaks followed since then and the annual incidence rate reached 0.5 per 1,000 population between 1997 and 2007. Outbreaks usually follow a seasonal pattern (that is,they occur during flooding in the rainy season), and cholera incidence on the archipelago was shown to be positively influenced by rainfall and temperature
Notes: Sampling from June through August 2008, exact dates assumed; used a vignette telling the respondents a story about a local person with the key signs and symptoms of cholera
Location Description:
Chumbuni: periurban slum-like extension of the capital of Zanzibar; characterized by a high population density of 15,300 people/km2 and brick houses with corrugated roofs
Muambe: coastline community with a population of approximately 8,000 people living in mud houses with thatched roofs in widely scattered hamlets
Comments: Only Zanzibar study extracted as other two studies already in this review

Title: Community-level burden of acute diarrhoeal illness in the first 2 years of life in Brisbane, Australia: A birth cohort study
Study Population: Women who gave birth to healthy, full-term children at two metropolitan hospitals
Case Definition: ADI: 3 ore more looose (liquid or looser than normal) stools within a 24-h period and included a refractory period of 3 days with no looes stools
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Reports on the ORChID study; Children born at selected hospitals submit symptom diaries (detailing disease episodes) and illness impact diaries (detailing care-seeking and other impacts) for the first two years (24 months) of life
Care Seeking Questions: What, if any, health-care was utilised during disease episode?
Comments: Total number of people surveyed is greater than the sum of people surveyed stratified by age. The upper limit of the age stratifications is 23 months but the study overall included children up to and including 24 months

Title: Determinants of Health Care Seeking for Diarrheal Illness in Young Children in Urban Slums of Kolkata, India
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5 living in a HUAS surveillance zone
Case Definition: MSD was defined as an acute diarrheal episode with three or more abnormally loose stools within the last 24 hours, and at least one of the following observations by the caretaker: sunken eyes (more than usual), wrinkled skin, receipt of intravenous rehydration, visible blood in stool, or hospitalization for diarrhea.
Study Context: Study part of GEMS project; HUAS done before case-control study started and HUAS-lites conducted during the study
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Exact dates assumed
Location Description: Registered slum areas in Wards 14, 31, 34, 58, and 59 in Eastern Kolkata; Streets are narrow with little space between houses, piped municipal water supply is intermittent, and several households share one or two latrines and water taps. At times the households are faced with extreme scarcity of water and overcrowded sanitary facilities. Most sewage is collected in open gutters that overflow during the rainy season. The underground water and sewage pipelines lie close to each other and are prone to leakage and contamination resulting in outbreaks
Additional Information: Licensed care providers were defined as practitioners having formal medical education, and a degree from a recognized institution
Comments: overlaps with study #40, this is marked as primary dataset due to inconsistencies in data reporting in study #40
Overlaps decision: Overlaps with study #40; 80 marked as primary dataset due to concerns about validity of care seeking in study #40. Care-seeking in table 3, defined as first source of care, adds up to over 100%. #80 additionally has care seeking information stratified by age and sex.

Location Description: Registered slum areas in Wards 14, 31, 34, 58, and 59 in Eastern Kolkata; Streets are narrow with little space between houses, piped municipal water supply is intermittent, and several households share one or two latrines and water taps. At times the households are faced with extreme scarcity of water and overcrowded sanitary facilities. Most sewage is collected in open gutters that overflow during the rainy season. The underground water and sewage pipelines lie close to each other and are prone to leakage and contamination resulting in outbreaks
Care Seeking Questions: Was care sought outside the home?
Diarrhea symptoms: at least one of the following: sunken eyes (more than usual), wrinkled skin, receipt of intravenous rehydration, visible blood in stool,
Overlaps decision: Overlaps with study #40; 80 marked as primary dataset due to concerns about validity of care seeking in study #40. Care-seeking in table 3, defined as first source of care, adds up to over 100%. #80 additionally has care seeking information stratified by age and sex.

Title: Changes in care-seeking for common childhood illnesses in the context of Integrated Community Case Management (iCCM) program implementation in Benishangul Gumuz region of Ethiopia
Study Population: Mothers/caregivers from the seven districts of the of the zone having children 2–59 months of age with at least one of the illnesses in the past two weeks were eligible for the survey
Case Definition: three or more loose stools per day in the reference period.
Study Context: Conducted before, during and after iCCM implementation
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: From 3 surveys conducted in January 2017, January 2018, and January 2019-exact dates assumed
Location Description: Benishangul Gumuz is among the four emerging regions of Ethiopia having low socio-economic status, limited access to social services and weak human resources to implement development programs including health service
Care Seeking Questions: Where did you first seek advice or treatment for diarrhea?

Study Population: Mothers/caregivers from the seven districts of the of the zone having children 2–59 months of age with at least one of the illnesses in the past two weeks were eligible for the survey
Case Definition: three or more loose stools per day in the reference period.
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: From January 2018, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Benishangul Gumuz is among the four emerging regions of Ethiopia having low socio-economic status, limited access to social services and weak human resources to implement development programs including health service

Title: Lived experience of acute gastrointestinal illness in Rigolet, Nunatsiavut: “Just suffer through it”
Study Population: All people in the community during the study period
Case Definition: AGI: vomiting and/or diarrhea not due to pregnancy, medication use, alcohol/drug use, or diagnosed chronic conditions
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Due to small population, census sample attemped; Sampling from September 2012 and May 2013, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Inuit community of Rigolet is situated in southern Nunatsiavut, on the north-east coast of Labrador; Rigolet has a young, growing Indigenous population of approximately 306 residents, 87% of whom identify as Aboriginal
Care Seeking Questions: When you have diarrhea or vomiting, what do you usually do?
Additional Information: For participants aged <12 years, the parent could act as a proxy respondent for the child and those 12+ answered for themselves

Title: Performance of a Community-based Health and Nutrition-education Intervention in the Management of Diarrhoea in a Slum of Delhi, India
Study Population: Mothers of children aged >12-71 months who were permanent residents of the area and did not work outside their homes
Study Context: A community-based health and nutrition-education intervention was being carried out to improve child health, with a special emphasis on diarrhea KAPs
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Precise Place Name: Jawahar camp, Harijan camp Harijan camp with Chuna Bhatti, Kirti Nagar
Location Description: Kirti Nagar is a neighborhood within the city of Delhi. Jawahar camp and Harijan camp with Chuna Bhatti are slums located within Kirti Nagar. There is a slum cluster located within the Kirti Nagar area. The cluster is densely populated with approximately 7,000 jhuggis (small dwelling units, mostly single-room structures, made up of mud or concrete or a mixture of both, each of them not exceeding more than 15 square yards in area). Jawahar and Harijan camps specifically chosen as study sites
Care Seeking Questions: What are your diarrhea management practices?

Title: Operationalising integrated community case management of childhood illnesses by community health workers in rural Haryana
Study Population: Mothers in households where there was a child aged 2–59 months, in the areas around Rasoolpur and Kalsada primary health centers
Case Definition: Diarrhoea defined as presence of the illness in the last 14 days as reported by mother
Study Context: Survey done before, during and after implementation of iCCM service delivering ASHAs
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: From 3 surveys conducted September-November 2015, April-May 2016 and September-October 2016, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Survey conducted in six subcentres of Rasoolpur and Kalsada  primary health centres (PHCs)
Additional Information: accredited social health activist
Comments: Sum of first source of care not equal to previously reported total who sought care; in recording first source of care some participants who sought care lost (n=43) [10 at baseline, 31 at midline and 2 at endline]

Title: Operationalising integrated community case management of childhood illnesses by community health workers in rural Haryana

Title: Care-seeking patterns among families that experienced under-five child mortality in rural Rwanda
Study Population: Caregivers of under-five deaths during study period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Caregivers identified from community and health facility records by triangulating existing MOH reporting systems and the Monitoring of Vital Events using Information Technology (MoVe-IT) program
Location Description: Conducted in the Kirehe District Hospital and Rwinkwavu District Hospital catchment areas; The terrain in rural Rwanda is hilly and the average walking distance from households to the nearest health facility in Kirehe is 92.4 minutes and 64.2 minutes in Kayonza
Additional Information: formal care defined as health workers or health facilities (health posts, health centers, hospitals, or private clinics)

Title: Effect of the Health Extension Program and Other Accessibility Factors on Care-Seeking Behaviors for Common Childhood Illnesses in Rural Ethiopia
Study Population: Mothers of children under 5 in rural woredas who had an episode of ARI, diarrhea or fever in the two peeks preceding the interview
Study Context: Following health extension program that provided children under 5 with case management through health extension workers using iCCM strategies
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from December 2012, exact dates assumed
GADM Admin 1, when available: Amhara, Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples, and Tigray
Comments: Inappropriate/none category not extracted

Title: Piloting a participatory, community-based health information system for strengthening community-based health services: findings of a cluster-randomized controlled trial in the slums of Freetown, Sierra Leone
Study Population: Mothers of children 0-23 months living in the target areas
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from May 2015, exact dates assumed
Precise Place Name: Allentown, Mabella, Susan's Bay, Grey Bush, Kingtom, Kuntorloh, Dwarzack, New England, Lumley, Malama
Location Description: 10 non-contiguous urban communities in Freetown; The communities in the study area are primarily unplanned, informal settlements characterized by overcrowding, low-quality housing, limited access to clean water, and lack of sanitation. Flooding is common in parts of the study area
Care Seeking Questions: Was care sought outside the home?

Title: Home Management of Diarrhea among Underfives in a Rural Community in Kenya: Household Perceptions and Practices
Study Population: Mothers/caregivers of under-fives residing in the study area for a period of at least six months
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: 1 district in each division randomly selected, then urban and rural clusters selected. Separately, clusters in slum and non-slum zones of cities of Dhaka and Chittagong also selected; Sampling from 2004-2006, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Lies in the eastern part of a large lowland surrounding the Nyanza Gulf (now Winam Gulf), much of it comprising of predominantly black cotton soils with poor drainage and perennial flooding. Study from before Kenya's 2010 constitution which changed the names and borders of its administrative divisions; the Province of Nyanza was divided to 6 counties, including Kisumu County, and Nyando Distrct became Nyando Constituency
Care Seeking Questions: What action wa taken during episode of diarrhea?

Title: Care-seeking behavior and out-of-pocket expenditure for sick newborns among urban poor in Lucknow, northern India: a prospective follow-up study
Study Population: Mothers giving birth at either the Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) center or a district hospital in Lucknow
Case Definition: Defined and classified as per the guidelines of National Neonatology Forum of India
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Infants enrolled within 24 hours of their birth and then their mothers were surveyed 6-8 weeks from then; Sampling from March-September 2007, exact dates assumed
Location Description:
Lucknow is the capital city of Uttar Pradesh, a state in Northern India and has a native population of 2.2 million. UNCHS estimates that currently more than half of Lucknow's urban population lives in slums
Study was conducted in two public hospitals, an urban Reproductive and Child Health center and a district hospital

Title: Healthcare-seeking behaviour in rural Ethiopia: evidence from clinical vignettes
Study Population: Heads of household, or their spouse, in districts that had undertaken healthcare financing reforms and were accessible by road to health centres
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Study presented participants with clinical vignettes of illnesses, including diarrhea, widely prevalent in the area. Diarrhea vignette describes 1 year old girl with diarrhea; Sampling from March-April 2011, exact dates assumed
GADM Admin 1, when available: Amhara, Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples, Oromiya, and Tigray
Care Seeking Questions: Scenario: A 1 year old girl, generally in good health, has diarrhea for 3 days now. She is still drinking some fluids, but since this morning, she’s feeling sleepy and doesn’t want to play. What would you do?

Title: Assessing trends in the content of maternal and child care following a health system strengthening initiative in rural Madagascar: A longitudinal cohort study
Study Population: men aged 15–59 and women aged 15–49 living in the enrolled households
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Survey following a health system strengthening (HSS) intervention inivitiate (PIVOT-MoH). PIVOT-MoH renovated, staffed, and equipped the hospital and health centers located in the catchment intervention area since mid-2014, as well as initiated a community health program in a subset of the catchment’s remote villages by November 2015. In addition, the partnership sought to remove logistical and financial barriers to medical care by creating an ambulance network and removing fees for commonly prescribed medications for all patients. PIVOT-MoH also implemented WHO’s Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) guidelines and national guidelines for the treatment for severe acute malnutrition, as well as had social workers at health facilities for the accompaniment and follow-up of vulnerable patients. Intervention group those who lived closest to supported those facilities, non-intervention group those who lived in closest to non-PIVOT-MoH facilities
Location Description: Intervention group villages surround PIVOT-supported health centers, mostly in the 4 middle communes (admin level 4) of Ifanadiana; Ifanadiana has an estimated population of 200,000 people, approximately one third of which live within intervention area

Title: Assessing trends in the content of maternal and child care following a health system strengthening initiative in rural Madagascar: A longitudinal cohort study
Study Population: men aged 15–59 and women aged 15–49 living in the enrolled households
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Survey following a health system strengthening (HSS) intervention inivitiate (PIVOT-MoH). PIVOT-MoH renovated, staffed, and equipped the hospital and health centers located in the catchment intervention area since mid-2014, as well as initiated a community health program in a subset of the catchment’s remote villages by November 2015. In addition, the partnership sought to remove logistical and financial barriers to medical care by creating an ambulance network and removing fees for commonly prescribed medications for all patients. PIVOT-MoH also implemented WHO’s Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) guidelines [39] and national guidelines for the treatment for severe acute malnutrition, as well as had social workers at health facilities for the accompaniment and follow-up of vulnerable patients.
Location Description: Intervention group villages surround PIVOT-supported health centers, mostly in the 4 middle communes (admin level 4) of Ifanadiana; Ifanadiana has an estimated population of 200,000 people, approximately one third of which live within intervention area

Title: Burden of Self-reported Acute Gastrointestinal Illness in Cuba
Study Population: Household members living in sentinel sites in Cuba
Case Definition: acute gastrointestinal illness as three or more bouts of loose stools in a 24-hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling meant to be household member with closest birthday, but most often whoever answered foor was interviewed, biasing sampe towards women 25-54 ; Sampling from June-July 2005, exact dates assumed
GADM Admin 1, when available: Cienfuegos, Ciudad de la Habana, Santiago de Cuba
GADM Admin 2, when available: Cienfuegos, Centro Habana, Santiago de Cuba
Location Description: Sites represent differences in urban-rural mix, from different regions of the country; sentinel sites represent ∼7.3% of the total Cuban population (11,241,291) in 2004
Care Seeking Questions: Did you go the physician for your illness?
Additional Information: Those 18 and older responded for themselves, ages 15-17 could respond for themselves or use a proxy and a parent or guardians answered for those under 15

Title: Self-care as a response to diarrhoea in rural Bangladesh: Empowered choice or enforced adoption?
Study Population: Household members in villages in Nilphamari
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: 3 villages in Nilphamari selected; Each village is situated within 10 km of the town with relatively good road links to it
Care Seeking Questions: What form of treatment was used?
Additional Information:
Text defined as: consultations with village practitioners who have received year-long training in diagnosing and treating common ailments. Community health workers also fall into this category, covering both government and NGO health workers operating at the village level.
1 month assumed to be 30 days

Title: Self-care as a response to diarrhoea in rural Bangladesh: Empowered choice or enforced adoption?
Study Population: Household members in villages in Nilphamari
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: 3 villages in Nilphamari selected; Each village is situated within 10 km of the town with relatively good road links to it
Care Seeking Questions: What form of treatment was used?
Additional Information:
Text defined as: includes treatment sought within faith healing and traditional systems of medicine, including kabiraj, herbalists and homeopathy practitioners
1 month assumed to be 30 days

Title: Self-care as a response to diarrhoea in rural Bangladesh: Empowered choice or enforced adoption?
Study Population: Household members in villages in Nilphamari
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: 3 villages in Nilphamari selected; Each village is situated within 10 km of the town with relatively good road links to it
Care Seeking Questions: What form of treatment was used?
Additional Information:
Text defined as: government and NGO health care facilities consisting of static clinic-based services providing mainly curative services from trained medical personnel.
1 month assumed to be 30 days

Title: Self-care as a response to diarrhoea in rural Bangladesh: Empowered choice or enforced adoption?
Study Population: Household members in villages in Nilphamari
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: 3 villages in Nilphamari selected; Each village is situated within 10 km of the town with relatively good road links to it
Care Seeking Questions: What form of treatment was used?
Additional Information:
Text defined as: untrained market sellers and road side ‘quacks’ that practice either allopathic or homeopathic medicine without any form of medical training or qualification.
1 month assumed to be 30 days

Title: Self-care as a response to diarrhoea in rural Bangladesh: Empowered choice or enforced adoption?
Study Population: Household members in villages in Nilphamari
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: 3 villages in Nilphamari selected; Each village is situated within 10 km of the town with relatively good road links to it
Care Seeking Questions: What form of treatment was used?
Additional Information:
Text defined as: individuals who have undergone professional medical training, normally lasting six years resulting in MBBS or BHMS qualifications for allopathic and homeopathic medicines, respectively.
1 month assumed to be 30 days

Title: An external evaluation of the Diarrhea Alleviation through Zinc and ORS Treatment (DAZT) program in Gujarat and Uttar Pradesh, India
Study Population: Caregivers of children aged 2-59 months
Case Definition: 3 loose or watery stools in a 24–hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Prior to implementation of the Diarrhea Alleviation through Zinc and ORS Treatment (DAZT) program. The main objective of the DAZT program was to scale–up adequate treatment of diarrhea among children under–five through public and private sector channels in selected districts. Sampling from March-June 2011, exact dates assumed
GADM Admin 2, when available: Banas Kantha, Dahod, Panchmahal, Patan, Sabar Kantha, Surendranagar

Title: Remoteness and maternal and child health service utilization in rural Liberia: A population–based survey
Study Population: Women, 17 and older, with a child under 5
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from August-September 2012, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Excluded 25 villages because: 19 had less than 20 households, four could only be reached on foot, and 2 were only accessible by canoe. Together, the excluded villages comprised 15% of Konobo’s rural population
Additional Information: Defined as registered facilities or healthcare workers, such as doctor, nurse, midwife or other medical provider at a health facility

Title: Measurements of quality of village-level care and patients’ healthcare-seeking behaviors in rural China
Study Population: Adults in households in selected villages
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Sampling from January 2018, exact dates assumed
Study assessing utilization of village clinics (VC), the frontline of primary healthcare in rural China, compared to bypassing use of VC for other facilities. Village clinics are responsible for village level public health services and primary diagnosis and treatment of common/frequent diseases.
Location Description: In 2017, the per capita GDP of Yunnan province was USD 5068, which was 42 percentage points lower than that of the national level (USD 8777)
Additional Information: VC: Village clinic

Title: Measurements of quality of village-level care and patients’ healthcare-seeking behaviors in rural China
Study Population: Adults in households in selected villages
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Sampling from January 2018, exact dates assumed
Study assessing utilization of village clinics (VC), the frontline of primary healthcare in rural China, compared to bypassing use of VC for other facilities. Village clinics are responsible for village level public health services and primary diagnosis and treatment of common/frequent diseases.
Location Description: In 2017, the per capita GDP of Yunnan province was USD 5068, which was 42 percentage points lower than that of the national level (USD 8777)
Additional Information: Bypassing refers to first seeking formal healthcare from higher-level facilities, including Township Health Centers, County Hospitals, and hospitals in urban areas

Title: Magnitude, Distribution, and  Estimated Level of Underreporting of Acute Gastroenteritis in Jamaica
Study Population: Anyone older than 1 year of age, not belonging to a vulnerable sub-population, in Jamaica
Case Definition: At least three loose within a 24-hour period, with or without associated symptoms
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from 21 February–7 March 2009,and 14-27 June, 2009; time periods selectde to reflect high and low prevalence seasons of AGE, as determined by trends from 2003-2007
Location Description: Included entire country of Jamaica
Additional Information: Adults answered on behalf of those under 18 and those 18 and older self-reported

Title: Quantitative and qualitative analysis of the knowledge, attitudes and social representations of cholera in the extreme northern region of Cameroon: the case of Maroua I, Maroua Ii And Mokolo
Study Population: Patients/clients visiting hospitals and household members in Mokolo, Maroua I and II
Case Definition: Cholera
Study Context: Likely following cholera outbreak; outbreak of 2009-2011 described as recent and, while no sampling dates mentioned, study submitted in 2013
Outbreak Description: The recent epidemic in the North of Cameroon from 2009 to the end of 2011 is the most severe of the cholera outbreaks in the history of the region
Care Seeking Questions: What do you do to treat yourself if you suspect you have cholera?
Comments: 89.87% (213/237) of respondents were male

Title: Health Care Utilization and Attitudes Survey: Understanding Diarrheal Diseasein Rural Gambia
Study Population: Primary caregivers of children under 5 in rural surveillance zones in Upper Region
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: HUA Survey; Study does not provide sampling dates, but from previous studies it has been noted that HUA Surveys, as part of the GEM Study, were conducted in 2007
Location Description: Upper River Region has an approximate population of 200,000, has one major town, Basse, but is otherwise typical of rural Africa; human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) prevalence is low (less than 2%)....indicate high (over 95%) immunization coverage. Most of the villages are served by the public water supply system piped to a communal tap shared by households. However, many households rely on bore holes and deep tube and open wells, because the public supply is unreliable
Care Seeking Questions: Was care sought outside the home?
Overlaps decision: Overlaps with study ID 40, 40 marked as primary dataset as it includes more descriptive care-seeking

Title: Determining the Community Prevalence of Acute Gastrointestinal Illness and Gaps in Surveillance of Acute Gastroenteritis and Foodborne Diseases in Guyana
Study Population: Household members living in regions 1-6 or 10
Case Definition: AGE: an acute (sudden) onset of diarrhoea
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling conducted during 14-28 August 2009 and 15-28 November 2009
GADM Admin 1, when available: Barima-Waini, Demerara-Mahaica, East Berbice-Corentyne, Essequibo Islands-West Demerara, Mahaica-Berbice, Pomeroon-Supenaam, Upper Demerara-Berbice
Location Description: Regions were the most-populated regions, accounting for approximately 84% of the population. The population is predominantly rural, with only 30% of the population living in one of the 6 towns
Additional Information: Adults (mother, father, or primary caregiver) answered for eligible children aged less than 12 years, those 12+ answered for themselves
Comments: Care seeking reported here sums to 18, total care seeking equal to 21 or 22 (study states both)

Title: Determinants of healthcare seeking for childhood illnesses among caregivers of under-five children in urban slums in Malawi: a population-based cross-sectional study
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5 who had lived in study setting for at least six months
Case Definition: three or more loose stools in a period of 24 h; 24 h typically entailed ‘for the whole day from morning to night’ or ‘started later in the day but continued into the night’ or ‘started in the night and continued to next morning’.
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from between October 2011 and February 2013, exact dates assumed
Location Description:
Exact locations are 3 slums surrounding Lilongwe, Malawi's capital city
Meet definition of urban slum: overcrowding; inadequate access to safe water; sanitation; insecurity of tenure; poor housing and inadequate public services
Care Seeking Questions: Was care sought outside the home?
Additional Information:
Care seeking defined as seeking healthcare from any biomedical health provider (health centre, central hospital, district hospital, public health centers, private health facilities)
3 months assumed to be 90 days

Title: Comparison of the burden of diarrhoeal illness among individuals with and without household cisterns in northeast Brazil
Study Population: Household members in selected villlages
Case Definition: 3 or more loose/liquid stools in a 24-hour period that was not due to a longterm illness, medication, overindulgence of alcohol or related to pregnancy.
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Households in selected communities with cisterns built prior to May 2006 and 1 child under 5 were recruited (all cases)
Households without cisterns were recruited by interviewers who, for every household with a cistern, also visited the next closest home without a cistern provided that they were not connected to a water system and had at least one child under the age of five years.
Additional Information: If an individual was under the age of 15 years or an elder (more than 60 years old), the head of the household could decide to respond on their behalf; otherwise individuals self reported

Title: Childhood Diarrhoea in a District in Northeast Thailand: Incidence and Treatment Choices
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5
Case Definition: Uses local terms for diarrhea; Tai (literally “to purge”) and tongsai, (literally “to have indigestion”) are general terms for unusual or abnormal stool such as watery stool, mucus and bloody stool. These terms could be used interchangeably and variably among the local people. For example, tongsai is much more formal than tai and is more likely to be used by urban residents, while tai is much more familiar among rural residents.
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from March-July 2002, exact dates assumed; Caregivers interviewed every two weeks for a period of two months
Location Description: 3 administrative communities studied;  The three communities comprised one community in town (population 596), one village near the town (population 638), and one village remote from the town (population 401).
Care Seeking Questions: What was the source of treatment?

Title: Health care seeking behavior for diarrhea in children under 5 in rural Niger: results of a cross-sectional survey
Study Population: Caretakers of children under 5
Case Definition: Acute watery diarrhea as more than 3 watery or liquid stools over a 24- hour period without the presence of blood
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: Madari is a city located within Madarounfa department, the third largest in Niger; Aguie, Gromoudji and Madarounfa are rural districts
Care Seeking Questions: What did you do when your child had diarrhea?

Title: Health care seeking behavior for diarrhea in children under 5 in rural Niger: results of a cross-sectional survey
Study Population: Caretakers of children under 5
Case Definition: Acute watery diarrhea as more than 3 watery or liquid stools over a 24- hour period without the presence of blood. Severe watery diarrhea was defined as acute watery diarrhea with the presence of at least two of the following signs: loss of consciousness and/or sunken eyes and/or incapable of drinking or drinking very little. Diarrhea was also considered severe if the child received intravenous rehydration treatment
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: Madari is a city located within Madarounfa department, the third largest in Niger; Aguie, Gromoudji and Madarounfa are rural districts
Care Seeking Questions: What did you do when your child had diarrhea?
Additional Information: Includes private clinics, regional or district hospitals, health ceners, health posts and "other"

Title: Community Case Management of Childhood Diarrhea in a Setting with Declining Use of Oral Rehydration Therapy: Findings from Cross-Sectional Studies among Primary Household Caregivers, Kenya, 2007
Study Population: Primary caregivers of children under 5 who had diarrhea in the preceding 2 weeks
Case Definition: three loose stools during a 24-hour period
Study Context: Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have conducted population based infectious disease surveillance in Asembo since 2004
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from 2007, exact dates assumed

Title: Caretaker’s perceptions, attitudes and practices regarding childhood febrile illness and diarrhoeal diseases among riparian communities of Lake Victoria, Tanzania
Study Population: Caretakers of children under 5
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
GADM Admin 1, when available: Mwanza, Mwanza, Mwanza, Mwanza, Kagera, Kagera, Kagera, Kagera, Mara, Mara, Mara, Mara
GADM Admin 2, when available: Sengerema, Sengerema, Geita, Geita, Muleba, Muleba, Bukoba, Bukoba, Tarime, Tarime, Musoma, Musoma

Location Description: Selected villages are part of the Lake Victoria basin, located on the lakeshore, and have two wet seasons, as well as regular rain

Title: Diarrhoea Episodes and Treatment-seeking Behaviour in a Slum Area of North Jakarta
Study Population: All members living living in a household for more than 6 months
Case Definition: Three or more loose bowel movements within a 24 hr period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from August-September 2001, exact dates assumed; A de jure census was taken
Location Description: Located in North Jakarta, these districts are representative of poor urban areas with a high incidence of diarrhea, especially cholera, in Jakarta; urban slums

Title: Estimating the Burden of Acute Gastrointestinal Illness in Grenada
Study Population: Household members in Grenada
Case Definition: An acute (sudden) onset of diarrhoea, with or without fever (>38 °C or 100.4 °F), presenting with three or more loose or watery stools within the past 24 hours, with or without vomiting, and/or visible blood in the stool
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from 44-46 weeks (10/27/08-11/16/08) in October 2008 to represent the low-AGE season, and the second survey was conducted during the 14-16 weeks (03/30/29-04/19/09)  in April 2009 to represent the high-AGE season.
Location Description: Includes entire country, all 6 parishes and the two dependency islands, Carriacou and Petite Martinique
Additional Information: Parents/guardians answered for those >12, those over 12 self-reported

Title: Factors Associated with Severe Dehydrating Diarrhoea in the Rural Western Cape, South Africa
Study Population: Caregivers of children aged 3-59 months attending Worcester Provincial Hospital (WPH) for diarrhoeal disease
Case Definition: Acute diarrhea: passage of unusually loose or fluid stools more frequent than normal for a period not exceeding 14 days
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Sampling from February-May 2014, exact dates assumed
All cases on predetermined randomly selected days were eligible for enrollment
Location Description: Worcester Provincial Hospital is a secondary level hospital
Care Seeking Questions: What type of healthcare facility was first attended?
