Title: Health Care Use Patterns for Diarrhea in Children in Low-Income Periurban Communities of Karachi, Pakistan
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5 living in a HUAS surveillance zone
Case Definition: Three or more abnormally loose stools in 24 hours
Study Context:
Study part of GEMS project; HUAS done before case-control study started
July-early September is rainy season (monsoon)
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: HUA Survey
Location Description: Three study sites are contiguous low-income communities approximately 20 km outside Karachi, where the Aga Khan University’s Department of Pediatrics and Child Health has maintained demographic surveillance since 2003. These communities are coastal settlements, with a total area of 8.1 miles squared. The residents of some areas have established piped water distribution networks by tapping the main municipal water supply. Where this network is not possible, residents have constructed community tanks or purchase water from vendors. The climate is subtropical, with monsoon rains in the summer months of June to September.
Overlaps decision: Overlaps with study #120; 120 marked as primary dataset due to concerns about validity of care seeking in study #40. Care-seeking in table 3, defined as first source of care, adds up to over 100%. #120 additionally has care seeking information stratified by age

The residents of some areas have established piped water distribution networks by tapping the main municipal water supply. Where this network is not possible, residents have constructed community tanks or purchase water from vendors. The climate is subtropical, with monsoon rains in the summer months of June to September.
Overlaps decision: Overlaps with study #120; 120 marked as primary dataset due to concerns about validity of care seeking in study #40. Care-seeking in table 3, defined as first source of care, adds up to over 100%. #120 additionally has care seeking information stratified by age

Title: Healthcare utilization and lost productivity due to infectious gastroenteritis, results from a national cross-sectional survey Australia 2008–2009
Study Population: Population of Australia
Case Definition: Gastroenteritis: 3 or more episodes of diarrhoea and/or 2 or more episodes of vomiting in a 24-h period over the previous 4 weeks, excluding cases who identified a non-infectious cause for their symptoms, such as pregnancy or consumption of alcohol
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from February 2008-January 2009, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Across all states and territories of Australia
Additional Information: Carers answered for children under 15, those 15 and older self-reported

Title: Health seeking behavior among Malaysians with acute diarrheal disease.
Study Population: Population of Malaysia
Case Definition: Three or more episodes of loose stool in a 24 hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from April to mid-August 2006, exact dates assumed

Care Seeking Questions: Was care sought outside the home?
Additional Information: Mothers or guardians answered for those 12 and younger, those 13 and older self-reported

Title: Health care utilization for acute illnesses in an urban setting with a refugee population in Nairobi, Kenya: a cross-sectional survey
Study Population: Household members in Eastleigh North Division
Case Definition: Three or more loose stools over a 24-hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Study attempted, in selection of location, to target refugees. By law in Kenya refugees are not restricted from accessing health care services from government-run facilities, but Kenyan law does require refugees to reside within designated refugee camps, which Eastwick is not. In response, the survey did not ask about immigration status/place of birth, but about the caretaker and his/her parent's place of birth. This information was used to identifty potential refugees, which the study estimates was approximately 50% of those sampled
Location Description: Most urban refugees from Somalia, Ethiopia, and Eritrea live in and around the neighborhood of Eastleigh, a suburb in eastern Nairobi inhabited largely by Somalis. The Somali population in Eastleigh includes both Kenyan nationals and people who have migrated from Somalia. The presence of this large Somali community in Eastleigh attracts new refugee arrivals from Somalia as well as from the two camp sites, Dadaab and Kakuma
Care Seeking Questions: Was health care sought? By what type of provider?
Additional Information: Caretakers served as proxies to answer questions for children less than 18 years of age or for people unavailable at the time of the interview; One month assumed to be 30 days
Comments: Care seeking information(did or did not) missing for one participant and one participant who sought care did not know the name of the site they visited

Title: Health care utilization for acute illnesses in an urban setting with a refugee population in Nairobi, Kenya: a cross-sectional survey
Study Population: Household members in Eastleigh North Division
Case Definition: Three or more loose stools over a 24-hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Study attempted, in selection of location, to target refugees. By law in Kenya refugees are not restricted from accessing health care services from government-run facilities, but Kenyan law does require refugees to reside within designated refugee camps, which Eastwick is not. In response, the survey did not ask about immigration status/place of birth, but about the caretaker and his/her parent's place of birth. This information was used to identifty potential refugees, which the study estimates was approximately 50% of those sampled
Location Description: Most urban refugees from Somalia, Ethiopia, and Eritrea live in and around the neighborhood of Eastleigh, a suburb in eastern Nairobi inhabited largely by Somalis. The Somali population in Eastleigh includes both Kenyan nationals and people who have migrated from Somalia. The presence of this large Somali community in Eastleigh attracts new refugee arrivals from Somalia as well as from the two camp sites, Dadaab and Kakuma
Care Seeking Questions: Was health care sought? By what type of provider?
Additional Information: Caretakers served as proxies to answer questions for children less than 18 years of age or for people unavailable at the time of the interview; One month assumed to be 30 days
Comments: Care seeking information(did or did not) missing for one participant and one participant who sought care did not know the name of the site they visited

Title: Health care utilization for acute illnesses in an urban setting with a refugee population in Nairobi, Kenya: a cross-sectional survey
Study Population: Household members in Eastleigh North Division
Case Definition: Three or more loose stools over a 24-hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Study attempted, in selection of location, to target refugees. By law in Kenya refugees are not restricted from accessing health care services from government-run facilities, but Kenyan law does require refugees to reside within designated refugee camps, which Eastwick is not. In response, the survey did not ask about immigration status/place of birth, but about the caretaker and his/her parent's place of birth. This information was used to identifty potential refugees, which the study estimates was approximately 50% of those sampled
Location Description: Most urban refugees from Somalia, Ethiopia, and Eritrea live in and around the neighborhood of Eastleigh, a suburb in eastern Nairobi inhabited largely by Somalis. The Somali population in Eastleigh includes both Kenyan nationals and people who have migrated from Somalia. The presence of this large Somali community in Eastleigh attracts new refugee arrivals from Somalia as well as from the two camp sites, Dadaab and Kakuma
Care Seeking Questions: Was health care sought? By what type of provider?
Additional Information:
Caretakers served as proxies to answer questions for children less than 18 years of age or for people unavailable at the time of the interview; One month assumed to be 30 days
Individuals included relatives, friends, religious leaders, traditionals healers and health volunteers
Comments: Care seeking information(did or did not) missing for one participant and one participant who sought care did not know the name of the site they visited

Title: Health Care Utilization and Attitudes Survey in Cases of Moderate-to-Severe Diarrheaamong Children Ages 0–59 Months in the District of Manhic¸a, Southern Mozambique
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5 living in a HUAS surveillance zone who had an episode of diarrhea in the past 14 days
Case Definition: Diarrhea: increased frequency and volume and decreased consistency from the norm
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: In Manhica, the climate is subtropical, with two distinct seasons: a warm and rainy season, usually spanning from November to April, and a generally cooler and drier season during the rest of the year. Area has high rates of malaria and HIV.
Care Seeking Questions: Where was care sought outside the home?
Overlaps decision: Overlaps with study #40; 124 marked as primary dataset due to concerns about validity of care seeking in study #40. Care-seeking in table 3, defined as first source of care, adds up to over 100%. #124 additionally has care seeking information stratified by age and sex.

Title: Health Care Utilization and Attitudes Survey in Cases of Moderate-to-Severe Diarrheaamong Children Ages 0–59 Months in the District of Manhic¸a, Southern Mozambique
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5 living in a HUAS surveillance zone who had an episode of diarrhea in the past 14 days
Case Definition:
Diarrhea: increased frequency and volume and decreased consistency from the norm
MSD: diarrhea with at least one of the following: (1) at least one of the following signs indicating MSD: sunken eyes significantly more than normal, wrinkled skin, or intravenous fluids administered at the health center (as referred by the mother in the interview), (2) dysentery (diarrhea with visible blood in stool), or (3) hospitalization for diarrhea or dysentery
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: In Manhica, the climate is subtropical, with two distinct seasons: a warm and rainy season, usually spanning from November to April, and a generally cooler and drier season during the rest of the year. Area has high rates of malaria and HIV.
Care Seeking Questions: Was care sought outside the home?
Diarrhea symptoms: (1) Sunken eyes significantly more than normal, wrinkled skin, or intravenous fluids administered at the health center (as referred by the mother in the interview), (2) dysentery (diarrhea with visible blood in stool), or (3) hospitalization for diarrhea or dysentery
Overlaps decision: Overlaps with study #40; 124 marked as primary dataset due to concerns about validity of care seeking in study #40. Care-seeking in table 3, defined as first source of care, adds up to over 100%. #124 additionally has care seeking information stratified by age and sex.

Title: Health Care Utilization and Attitudes Survey in Cases of Moderate-to-Severe Diarrheaamong Children Ages 0–59 Months in the District of Manhic¸a, Southern Mozambique
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5 living in a HUAS surveillance zone who had an episode of diarrhea in the past 14 days
Case Definition: Diarrhea: increased frequency and volume and decreased consistency from the norm
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: In Manhica, the climate is subtropical, with two distinct seasons: a warm and rainy season, usually spanning from November to April, and a generally cooler and drier season during the rest of the year. Area has high rates of malaria and HIV.
Care Seeking Questions: Would you seek care outside of the home in case of diarrhea?
Overlaps decision: Overlaps with study #40; 124 marked as primary dataset due to concerns about validity of care seeking in study #40. Care-seeking in table 3, defined as first source of care, adds up to over 100%. #124 additionally has care seeking information stratified by age and sex.

Title: Health Care Utilization and Attitudes Survey in Cases of Moderate-to-Severe Diarrheaamong Children Ages 0–59 Months in the District of Manhic¸a, Southern Mozambique
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5 living in a HUAS surveillance zone who had an episode of diarrhea in the past 14 days
Case Definition: Diarrhea: increased frequency and volume and decreased consistency from the norm
Study Context: Sampling periods accounted for changes in healthcare use that may occur because of seasonality (flooding, harvest season, holidays) or secular events (elections, unrest)
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling included a series of four repeated cross-sectional assessments that took place between February 16, 2009 and December 30, 2010.
Location Description: In Manhica, the climate is subtropical, with two distinct seasons: a warm and rainy season, usually spanning from November to April, and a generally cooler and drier season during the rest of the year. Area has high rates of malaria and HIV.
Care Seeking Questions: Where was care sought outside the home?

Title: Effectiveness of Zinc Supplementation Plus Oral Rehydration Salts Compared With Oral Rehydration Salts Alone as a Treatment for Acute Diarrhea in a Primary Care Setting: A Cluster Randomized Trial
Study Population: Caregivers of children 1-59 months living in areas covered by six primary health centers in Haryana India
Case Definition:
In those <2 months: recent change in consistency and/or frequency of stools
In older children: 3 or more loose or watery stools in a 24 hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Study from January 2005-September 2006, exact dates assumed; Survey 2 occured 3 months after first evaluation survey
PHC clusters with similar SES indocator scores were paired and in each pair, one group was randomly allocated to the intervention group and the other to the control group. Then all eligible within the cluster were interviewed.
Intervention group received (1) training in diarrhea management  (2) improved availability of Zinc and ORS (3) promotion of diarrhea treatment through the primary health care system. Intervention delivered through government providers,  Anganwadi workers and private practitioners
Comments: Survey 1 did not report care-seeking for diarrhea

Study from January 2005-September 2006, exact dates assumed; Survey 2 occured 3 months after first evaluation survey
PHC clusters with similar SES indocator scores were paired and in each pair, one group was randomly allocated to the intervention group and the other to the control group. Then all eligible within the cluster were interviewed.
Intervention group received (1) training in diarrhea management  (2) improved availability of Zinc and ORS (3) promotion of diarrhea treatment through the primary health care system. Intervention delivered through government providers,  Anganwadi workers and private practitioners
Comments: Survey 1 did not report care-seeking for diarrhea

Title: Family self-medication for children in an urban area of Nigeria
Study Population: Mothers of students in primary 1 to 5 in selected private and publiuc schools in urban areas in Lagos
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Location Description: Ten public schools and 10 private schools were selected in Lagos state by selecting two schools each from ﬁve urban local government areas
Care Seeking Questions: What intervention was sought for symptom?
Additional Information: 1 month assumed to be 30 days
Comments: Surveyed students in primary 1-5, search determined primary 1 is started at age 6 and so ages assumed to correspond to that timeline

Title: Narrowing the treatment gap with equitable access: mid-term outcomes of a community case management program in Cameroon
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5 living in rural villages of selected districts
Study Context: The study period overlapped with one of two annual rainy seasons in Cameroon (March–June and September–November
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Intervention: Community health workers (CHW) were systematically trained in community care management, were assigned to catchment areas and provided with supplies to treat common childhood illnesses. The CHWs were supervised by facility-based health workers who could re-equip CHWs with supplies.
Location Description: Thick rainforests support the breeding of disease vectors including anopheles mosquitoes, and the primary livelihood is subsistence farming. Transportation in the region is limited by a lack of infrastructure; three main roads cover the territory

Notes: Comparison: CHWs provided current national standard of care for treatment of childhood illnesses, but did not have NGO support for the commuinty health workers, community health workers trained in community care management and workers were not supplied with medicines

Title: Home-based management of acute diarrhoeal disease in an urban slum of Aligarh, India
Study Population: Caretakers of children less than 60 months living in a peri-urban slum
Case Definition: Three or more loose stools in a day, with or without blood or mucous in stools
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from June and July 2009, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Study area was a "peri-urban slum"
Care Seeking Questions: What type of services were used?
Comments: 61% (62/101) were 13 months or older

Title: Impact of NGO Training and Support Intervention on Diarrhoea Management Practices in a Rural Community of Bangladesh: An Uncontrolled, Single-Arm Trial
Study Population: Caretakers of children 6-59 months who had diarrhea in the two weeks preceding interview living in selected rural villages
Case Definition: Diarrhea: lasting two or more days
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Sampling from a baseline survey (February 2008) and an endline survey (August 2008), exact dates assumed. 
Intervention offered training/refresher course to the health care providers in selected villages regarding zinc treatment in childhood diarrhoea through NGO health care providers. In addition, the NGO conducted community-based promotion of zinc treatment in the intervention villages. Participants blind to study

Title: Health-seeking patterns among participants of population-based morbidity surveillance in rural western Kenya: implications for calculating disease rates
Study Population: Individuals living in villages that were at least 50% of the village lives within five miles of Lwak Hospital and were registered as disease surveillence system for at least four continuous months
Case Definition: At least three looser than normal stools were reported during a 24-h period.
Study Context: Part of a demographic surveillance system (DSS), run by the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) since 2001
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Participants were interviewed every 2 weeks to record illness during the past 2 weeks
Rainfall is seasonal with the heaviest (long) rains usually occurring from March through May and short rains falling between September and November
Location Description: Borders Lake Victoria; Bondo District is one of the most impoverished districts in Kenya with 70% of the population living below the poverty line.10 There are a few clay or soil roads in the area and one tarmac road, completed in 2006 and the area has a high HIV prevalence rate

Study Population: Households with under-five children with diarrhea in Debre Berhan town in during the study period

Title: Effect of implementation of integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness programme on treatment seeking practices for morbidities in infants: cluster randomised trial.
Study Population: Infants born in communities enrolled in the study area
Case Definition: Caregiver report of diarrhea
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Intervention areas received home visits during newborn period by community health workers, trained healthcare workers in case management of sick children using integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness, ensured availability of essential medicines and provided supervision of and perfomance based incentives to community health workers
Recruitment period was January 2008-March 2010, exact dates assumed. Interviews took place when child was 29 days old, at 6 months old and at 12 months old.
Additional Information: Physicians in government hospital and primary health centres;

Title: Estimated Burden of Human Salmonella, Shigella, and Brucella Infections in Jordan, 2003–2004
Study Population: All persons, age >1, who were present in Jordan during August 2003
Case Definition: 3 loose stools that took the shape of a container in a 24-hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Nationwide cross-sectional surveys were conducted during September 2003, exact dates assumed
Location Description: National survey, includes both urban and rural areas
Facility or location sought as written i: Medical care, excluding the Ministry of Health
Additional Information: Includes data on young children whose age makes self-response impossible, or unlikely, but text does not specify at what age participants are allowed to self-report vs have a proxy answer on their behalf.

Title: Estimating the burden of acute gastrointestinalillness in the community in Gansu Province,northwest China, 2012–2013
Study Population: Household members living in Baiyin, Liangzhou or Qingcheng during the study period
Case Definition: Gastroenteritis was defined for this study as an individual with ≥ 3 loose stools, or any vomiting, for a period of 24 h
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from June 2012-May 2013, exact dates assumed
Location Description: The study sites were selected based on their geographic location, population density, level of economic development and predefined risk rating
Additional Information: Proxy respondents were used for study participants aged < 12 years and for individuals aged between 12 and 16 years when parental or guardian consent was not given to interview them directly. Those 17 and older self-reported

Title: Evaluation of Integrated Community Case Management in Eight Districts of Central Uganda
Study Population: Households with under-five children in the study area
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Sampling from October 2010, exact dates assumed
Prior to study where integrated community case management (iCCM) was implemeneted in interventions districts. This trained vilage health teams in iCCM strategies, enabled them to diagnose and treat common illnesses, provided them with necessary medicines and provided supervision.
Precise Place Name: Wakiso, Mpigi, Butambala, Gomba, Masaka, Lwengo, Bukomansimbi and Kalungu
Location Description: Three (Government then divided the 3 into 8) intervention districts were selected based on the following: 1) a high poverty score, 2) a high expected absolute number of annual under five deaths, 3) existence of partners with iCCM capacity and 4) exclusion of districts that already had partners delivering iCCM

Title: Evaluation of Integrated Community Case Management in Eight Districts of Central Uganda

Case Definition: Cholera
Outbreak Description: The study area had reported several cholera outbreaks between 2017 and 2018.
Notes: Sampling from February 2018, exact dates assumed
Location Description: The population consists largely of nomadic pastoralists who live in rural areas where access to safe drinking water is limited
Care Seeking Questions: Where would you go for care if you or your family member had cholera?
Additional Information: Self or other family member
Comments: Data extrated manually from study's excel datasheet by MHM using pivot tables in excel. Worksheet showing extraction process can be found in Extraction file in Care Seeking Review channel on Teams

Case Definition: Cholera
Outbreak Description: The study area had reported several cholera outbreaks between 2017 and 2018.
Notes: Sampling from February 2018, exact dates assumed
Location Description: The population consists largely of nomadic pastoralists who live in rural areas where access to safe drinking water is limited
Care Seeking Questions: Where would you go for care if you or your family member had cholera?
Additional Information: Self or other family member
Comments: Data extrated manually from study's excel datasheet by MHM using pivot tables in excel. Worksheet showing extraction process can be found in Extraction file in Care Seeking Review channel on Teams

Title: Resistance pattern and maternal knowledge, attitude and practices of suspected Diarrheagenic Escherichia coli among children under 5 years of age in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia: cross sectional study
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5 attending at outpatient pediatric departments of selected health institutions (Selam health center, Addis Ketema health center, and St. Paul’s Hospital Millennium Medical College) for diarrheal illnesses
Case Definition: Diarrhea: at least three loose stools in 24 h including at least one of nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps or fever symptoms
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from August-September 2018, exact dates assumed
Precise Place Name: Selam health center, Addis Ketema health center, and St. Paul’s Hospital Millennium Medical College
Location Description: Addis Ababa is the capital and largest city of Ethiopia.

Title: Prevalence, risk factors and treatment practices in diarrhoeal diseases in south India
Study Population: Household members in Jeppinamogaru or Ullal
Case Definition: Diarrhoea was defined as passage of at least three loose stools in 24 h. Acute diarrhoea was defined as diarrhea that which lasts lesser than 14 days
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from February 2013, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Mangalore is a coastal city located in south western part of Karnataka state between Arabian Sea and Western Ghat mountain ranges. Study population included semi-urban area of Jeppinamogaru and rural area of Ullal
Additional Information: Respondents answered for themselves and all members of their households
Comments: 34/69 of cases among those <10 years old

Title: The burden of self-reported acute gastrointestinal illness in Italy: a retrospective survey, 2008-2009.
Study Population: Residents in Italy with access to a private telephone landline
Case Definition: AGI: three or more loose stools or any vomiting in a 24-h period that was not due to the consumption of drugs or alcohol, excluding those with cancer of the bowel, irritable bowel syndrome, Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, cystic fibrosis, coeliac disease or other chronic illnesses with symptoms of diarrhoea or vomiting.
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from June 2008-July 2009, exact dates assumed; Interviews administered at the beginning of each month (first 2 days)
Additional Information:
Recall period defined as "identical to the previous calendar month;" assumed to be 30 days
Parents/guadirans answered on behalf of participants aged <18 and those 18+ self-reported
Comments: Estimated 67% of Italian households had acces to a private landline in 2009

Title: Risk Factors for Diarrhoea and Upper Respiratory Tract Infections among Child in a Rural Area of Uganda
Study Population: Women with children under 2 living in the study area
Case Definition: Diarrhea: watery stools that occur more frequently than usual and is associated with weakness
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from 2001, exact dates assumed

Study Population: Women with children under 2 living in the study area
Case Definition: Diarrhea: watery stools that occur more frequently than usual and is associated with weakness
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description

Title: Prevalence of oral rehydration therapy use and associated factors among under-five children with diarrhea in Dangure, Benishangul Gumuz Region, Ethiopia/2018
Study Population: Caregivers of children under 5 who had diarrhea in the past two weeks in the study area
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from February-March 2018, exact dates assumed
Care Seeking Questions: Do you have behavior of seeking treatment from health facilities?

Title: The burden of acute gastrointestinal illness in Ontario, Canada, 2005–2006
Study Population: Residents in Ontario with access to telephones
Case Definition: Diarrhoea: stool with abnormal liquidity or any loose stool
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from May 2005-April 2006, exact dates assumed; telephone survey
Location Description: The province of Ontario is located in central Canada, and has an estimated population of y12. 5 million, representing about 40% of the Canadian population. The population is concentrated in the southern part of the province, which consists of large urban centres surrounded by suburban and rural areas. The northern part of the province has a more widely distributed population. 84.7% of survey respondents lived in urban areas
Additional Information: Proxy respondents were used when the selected participant was aged <12 years, when the selected participant was aged between 12 and 18 years and their parent or guardian felt that the child would not be able to answer the questions themselves, or when the selected participant was aged >18 years and had a developmental or intellectual disability such that their parent or guardian felt that they would not be able to answer the questions themselves.

Title: The Incidence of Acute Gastrointestinal Illness in Canada, Foodbook Survey 2014-2015
Study Population: Household members in Canada with access to telephones (landline or cell phone) who had not travelled outside their province or territory of residence in the seven days prior to the interview
Case Definition: AGI: three or more loose stools in 24 hours or any vomiting in the past 28 days, OR three or more loose stools in 24 hours or any vomiting in the past 28 days without concurrent respiratory symptoms (cough or sore throat)
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from April 2014-April 2015, exact dates assumed; Telephone sample, including both landline and cell phone numbers
Location Description: Study conducted in all 10 provinces and 3 territories; Northern Québec, Northern Ontario and the territories (Yukon, Northwest Territories, and Nunavut) have proportionally more residents living in remote rural areas without access to a telephone or a cell phone and therefore, these Canadians are not well-represented.
Additional Information: Proxy respondents were used in accordance with provincial and territorial laws for participants under a certain age, or for those unable to respond on their own behalf. If the selected individual was under the age of consent, the interview was conducted with the child’s parent or legal guardian, or with another adult knowledgeable about the child’s activities at the discretion of the parent or legal guardian. Proxy response was also allowed for individuals with medical or activity limitations
Comments: Data weighted to adjust for data lost when the survey tool used made an error and did not ask all survey questions. An adjustment for missing data was made by weighting completed interviews for respondents that reported symptoms of diarrhea only (April 2014 to October 2014; weighted n = 988,114.51) to account for the missing data (November 2014 to April 2015; weighted n = 855,500.56) by province (and respiratory symptoms for the more specific case definition), therefore increasing the weight assigned to the completed interviews (Appendix A). An assumption was made that there would be similar chronic disease and duration of symptoms between the diarrhea-only cases from April to October and November to April.

Title: Quantifying the incidence and cost of acute gastrointestinal illness in Sweden, 2013–2014
Study Population: Swedish residents, up to age 85, who were enrolled in Hälsorapport,  a public health surveillance program in Sweden
Case Definition: AGI: 3 or more loose stools in 24 h or vomiting 3 or more times in 24 h or loose stools with 2+ additional symptoms in 24 h or vomiting with 2+ additional symptoms in 24 h
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: The first three weeks of surveillance were excluded from analysis (care-seeking questionnaires began December 9, 2013)
Care Seeking Questions: Did you seek health care because of these symptoms?
Additional Information: Proxy respondents answered on behalf of those under age 16. Those 16 and older self-reported

Title: Quantifying the incidence and cost of acute gastrointestinal illness in Sweden, 2013–2014

Case Definition: AGI: 3 or more loose stools in 24 h or vomiting 3 or more times in 24 h or loose stools with 2+ additional symptoms in 24 h or vomiting with 2+ additional symptoms in 24 h

Title: Mortality and health survey, Walikale, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 2017: an example of the use of survey data for humanitarian program planning
Study Population: Household members in villages in the catchment area of the Médecins Sans Frontières Walikale project
Study Context:
The area has experienced decades of political unrest and conflict 
There were no formal IDP camps within the study area at the time of the survey and the majority of displaced persons were sheltered within host communities.
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Médecins Sans Frontières ~ doctors without borders; support local health facilities
Sampling from December 2017, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Villages in the catchment area of the MSF Walikale project were selected including the health zones of Walikale and Lowa, both of which are in the Walikale territory
Care Seeking Questions: Did this person receive health care?
Additional Information: Those 16 and older self-reported and reported for all others in household, including children

Title: Quantifying antimicrobial access and usage for paediatric diarrhoeal disease in an urban community setting in Asia
Study Population: Parents or caregivers of children 1-4 years who were of residents of District 8
Case Definition: 4-5 loose stools in the last 24 hours, no blood or mucus seen in stool and no fever
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Caregivers asked about care choices if their child had diarrhea in simulated scenarios
Location Description: District 8 has  a population density of 22522 people/km2 and was chosen as the location for sampling owing to its urban setting and central location
Care Seeking Questions: Would you visit this healthcare service as a first, second or third choice for care?
Additional Information: Participants asked were they would go first, then second and then third. Results aggregate of number of participants who listed the service as any of the choices, as data not available for the order of choice

Case Definition: 4-5 loose stools in the last 24 hours, with blood or mucus seen in stool and child has fever
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Caregivers asked about care choices if their child had diarrhea in simulated scenarios
Location Description: District 8 has  a population density of 22522 people/km2 and was chosen as the location for sampling owing to its urban setting and central location
Care Seeking Questions: Would you visit this healthcare service as a first, second or third choice for care?
Additional Information: Participants asked were they would go first, then second and then third. Results aggregate of number of participants who listed the service as any of the choices, as data not available for the order of choice
Diarrhea symptoms: Mucus or blood in stool and fever

Title: Sociodemographic Determinants of Healthcare-Seeking Options and Alternative Management Practices of Childhood Diarrheal Illness: A Household Survey among Mothers in Iraq
Study Population: Mothers, 18 years old or older, of children with a child younger than 5 years old
Case Definition: Loose watery stool with or without blood continuously for more than three times in any particular day
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from March 2016-February 2017, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Thi-Qar Governorate was targeted in this study because it is considered as the least developed governorate in Iraq, with 37.8% of the population living below the poverty line of US$ 2.5/day. The economy of Thi-Qar is largely rural and dependent on livestock and crop production

Title: Health Care Utilization and Symptom Severity in Ghanaian Children – a Cross-Sectional Study
Study Population: Caregivers of children up to 12 years old who had lived in the study area for at least six months
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from March-September 2008, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Survey conducted in the Agogo Presbyterian Hospital (APH) and Konongo-Odusami Hospital (KOH) catchment areas. The study area has a rural character with an estimated population of 170,000 inhabitants spread over 1,160 square kilometers. The climate is tropical and the region is mainly covered by secondary rain forest and cultivated land
Care Seeking Questions: Would you go to the hospital?

Title: Prevalence of Childhood Illnesses and Care-Seeking Practices in Rural Uganda
Study Population: Women with children aged less than 24 months
Case Definition: Watery stools that occured at least three times a day
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from 2001, exact dates assumed
Location Description: The Sembabule district lies in a remote area in Central Uganda. The district has a poor road network and is served by one health center and five dispensaries. The district has a flat geographical terrain with a poor source of clean water. Those that live there include farmers, agricultural peasants and nomadic pastroralists. The district has two dry seasons from December to March and from May to July.

Title: Local perceptions of cholera and anticipated vaccine acceptance in Katanga province, Democratic Republic of Congo
Study Population: Adults above 18 years of age who had lived in the residence for at least six months
Case Definition: profuse watery diarrhoea
Study Context: While no outbreak was occuring during/immediately before the study dates, the area has experienced several in the past
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Sampling from August and September 2010, exact dates assumed
Location Description: The study was conducted in a rural town (Kasenga) along the Luapula River and on a fishing island (Nkolé) in Lake Mweru, Katanga Province, DRC. Kasenga has approximately 27,000 inhabitants. Electricity, water and two mobile communication networks are available. Health facilities include a district hospital, several clinics and dispensaries, and private pharmacies. Nkolé, a remote rural settlement, is inhabited by approximately 7000 people. Only one rural health centre was functional. The nearest referral centre could be reached only by boat
Care Seeking Questions: Where would you go for treatment of cholera?
Comments: Using google maps and the DRC's GADM shapfile, Nkolé was determined to be in Lubumbashi

Title: Incidence of severe diarrhoea due to Vibrio cholerae in the catchment area of six surveillance hospitals in Bangladesh
Study Population: Household members living in the defined hospital catchment areas who were admitted to surveillance hospitals in the previous 12 months.
Case Definition: Severe diarrhoea: frequent loose or liquid stools for which a person had to be admitted to a healthcare facility, or had to receive intravenous rehydration, or had died as a result of the diarrhoeal illness.
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
In urban areas, sampling was done by starting from the centrepoint of a cluster and proceeding in a randomly chosen direction, the team visited all the households until they identified 10,000 cases. In rural areas, severe diarrhea cases were identified by community members/healthcare workers in the area and confirmed by researchers
Sampling from December 2010-April 2011, exact dates assumed
Location Description: Study took place in the catchment areas of several hospitals. Dhaka Hospital and Mirpur Treatment Centres, both in the capital, serve urban population of Dhaka and nearby area.  Matlab, Kumudini, Chhatak, and Mathbaria hospitals all mainly serve rural populations. Kumudini is a plain area, Chhatak is in a low-lying, flood-prone area and Mathbaria is adjacent to the coast of the Bay of Bengal.
Care Seeking Questions: Did you seek care from a qualified healthcare provider on your first visit?
Additional Information: Respondents answered on behalf of the household, including themself, children and other adult members.
Comments: 32% (2089) of cases in all districts were among children less than 5. Data not available for each individual district

Title: Incidence, Etiology, and Healthcare Utilization for Acute Gastroenteritis in the Community, United States
Study Population: English-speaking Kaiser Permanete Northwest enrollees in northwest Oregon and southwest Washington who were not decisionally or cognitively impaired
Case Definition: Acute diarrhea: 3 or more loose stools in any 24 hour period
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes: Kaiser Permanente Northwest (KPNW) is an integrated health care delivery system serving northwest Oregon and southwest Washington
Location Description:
KPNW states its local markets include Portland, Eugene and Salem, Oregon and Vancouver and Lonview/Kelso, Washington
This network comprises 24% of, and is demographically similar to, the underlying population of northwest Oregon and southwest Washington, USA
Care Seeking Questions: Did you have a healthcare encounter within Kaiser Permanente Northwest?
Additional Information:
Sample included aged 0-65+, unclear at what age respondents self-reported versus used a proxy even though certain ages would certainly require a proxy. 
In person: inpatient visit, urgent care, emergency department or outpatient visit

Title: Operational Issues and Trends Associated with the Pilot Introduction of Zinc for Childhood Diarrhoea in Bougouni District, Mali
Study Population: Caretakers of young children with diarrhea in the previous two weeks
Outbreak Description: No outbreak description
Notes:
Sampling from April 2004, exact dates assumed
Prior to implementation of program promoting zinc use for childhood diarrhea.
Facility or location sought as written i: Community health centre or referral health centre
Comments: Text does not state what age(s) constitute "young children" but the introduction does provide statistics for under-five mortality and morbidity.
